tags: not really just to be safe
summary: I know people are exciting about this new promo. I am too but i always like to think the worse. Maybe the things will not play...
question: I know people are exciting about this new promo. I am too but i always like to think the worse. Maybe the things will not play like we think. Maybe jon told dany to wait while he tried to convinced sansa to play nice and accept her. Maybe he tell sansa be nice when they hug or i trust her o i love her o something like that maybe then he turns to face dany and tell her that she can get close. Maybe that is why he looks like nodding his head like is ok to come.
answer:
(2) And he introduces daenerys to sansa like queen of westeros and blah blah blah maybe that is why dany smiles smugly. Maybe he defends her and that is why jorah and dany looks like proud of jon or something like: we got this             

Dear nonny,

I do think it is safe to assume that in the few seconds we had there will be no additional dialogue. It would be somewhat much to cut something out just so that a few delulu shippers will get duped. As far as I remember we always saw actual tidbits.

The wider context is something completely different of course and it is possible that Jon tells Dany to wait. That wouldn’t be too bad though. Whatever Jon’s feelings, it might be a good idea to be the first to greet Sansa and smooth things over.

Although I would say that Jon’s face we saw in the first promo did not look like someone who urgently wanted to say something. It looked like someone who wanted to get home and into the arms of someone dear.

I think it is possible that Jon whispered something in Sansa’s ear when they hugged. You could interprete Sansa’s side eyes as her snapping to attention after Jon whispered something. We will see when episode 1 airs.

I don’t think that we will have more dialogue in these few seconds we saw, so no reciting of many titles etc. Another anon saw wide mist coming from Jon’s mouth and also suspected he said something, but I doubt it. @athimbleful made a gifset of this scene side by side with the discussion Jon and Sansa have with Lord Glover and there you can see that Jon’s breath puffs mist in the air as well - but he doesn’t say anything in that scene either.

For Jorah I would say that the explanation by @athimbleful makes more sense. Jorah rejoices because he sees that Jon is indeed not that much into D and sees his own star rising again or his suspicions confirmed.

As for D’s smug smile: it is clearly directed at Sansa. It says: mine, mine and is the smile of the type ‘mean girl’ that comes as an early triumph because the boy is hers. If she were proud of Jon, she would smile at Jon and with a nicer more render smile - just my interpretation of course.

I think that the whole scene is set up to remember us of King Robert’s arrival. And the differences are significant. Sansa bids D welcome in the exact same wording as Ned, an ambiguous wording that could mean 'welcome to Winterfell’ or 'my loyalty is yours’. With Ned it meant both, with Sansa it means none of the above but is just hollow words. The visual differences are also significant. Nobody kneels, D and Jorah are set in opposite to Jon and Sansa. Jon joins team Winterfell before D comes close. The shots of D, Jon and Sansa are shots that hint at a love triangle.

All in all I don’t think that this is meant to be a warm welcome or even the attempt for one by Jon. If Jon would have wanted to orchestrate the greeting he could have either escorted Dany as the loyal Warden he supposedly is or he could have come in advance and could have prepared everybody to kneel to give a proper welcome to the Queen as we saw it in the pilot.

As always with scenes with Jon and D my mind can come up with little twists that would make these far less ambiguous. I’m in no way a film expert.. That I can come up with a different scenario more positive for Jon€nerys is telling I think. I hope to have diverted you from your fears somewhat. 😇

Thanks for the ask!

blog.description: A bad idea written down is far better and far more useful to you than a blank sheet of paper and a mythical piece of brilliance that has been stuck in your head out of fear of failure. Go ahead and fail. Then make it better.

summary:
“She’s now in a very unfamiliar situation in that she cannot
just threaten people into submission because she’s infatuated with...
body:
“She’s now in a very unfamiliar situation in that she cannot just threaten people into submission because she’s infatuated with Jon and wants him to like her. She has to play a game of courtesy, which was never her strong suit… As her dragons and armies grew, she never had the need to be a diplomat and be polite to the people she negotiated with because she had all the hard power and she wasn’t averse to using it.”

A small fraction of @trinuviel‘s breakdown of Daenery’s outfit in the teaser and what it represents. Read Here 

This aspect of Dany’s journey is very interesting to me.

As she’s hasn’t really had to play the long game of politics or “playing nice” with others, especially with those she doesn’t like. And it might be hard to see that as a flaw of hers.

In the past seasons, we’ve like that about Daenerys. We also like that about Jon Snow, Arya Stark, Ned Stark and Olenna Tyrell – cutting through the bullshit with blunt honesty. Being direct and concise and not playing the stupid and pointless political games.

These characters are often performing a wish-fulfillment for the audience, we would love to tell off other people who are clearly not doing what they should be doing and just cut through all the fake-smiles. 

Especially if you work in the service industry. 

Or sometimes the character does what we want to see happen in our own real-world politics.

It’s not exactly a bad trait, but it’s also certainly not a good one (honestly, it depends on the situation).

Daenerys not really knowing how to or I would argue, not really having the patience for the long game, isn’t a strength of hers, though. And personally, I see that as more of a flaw.

In life, you have to play nice. 

And in the world of Westeros, you have to play the political game. You don’t have to fight for the Iron Throne like Cersei (and Dany and others think), but you are part of the overall scheme.

And this is also where the difference between Conquerors and Queens/Kings comes into play. You have to get people on your side and currently when there are multiple “heirs” for the Iron Throne, that’s more important than ever.

You want people to want you on the Throne. And no major groups of people in Westeros actively want Daenerys on the Throne. They also don’t want Cersei, but if your best-selling point is that you might be slightly better than Cersei Lannister…well, good luck with that.

A conqueror or tyrant threatens and uses hard or violent power and while a King/Queen can also do that, arguably that leaves more of a bad impression and an even worse taste in one’s mouth. 

Cersei is not a good queen for blowing up the Sept. Joffrey was not a good king for hurting Sansa. And King Aerys II was not a good king for torturing and killing his subjects.

Bad blood begins to spill over – 2 out of 3, so far, have been killed by those they ‘trusted’ or at least would never suspect.

Dany should’ve learned from Meereen – conquering and ruling are two very different beasts. One can be done in an “instant” and the other is never truly done, you will always have to work – if you are to be a good ruler or leader.

And Dany lacks that patience.

So, depending on how long the political drama/game goes on between Daenerys and the Starks, I am interested to see how Dany handles it.

I personally believe, Daenerys will get frustrated with Sansa. Who I think will never be open or exactly warm to her, but always courteous and polite. Which yeah, that would be frustrating from Dany’s POV, but you have to still grin and bear it. 

Or maybe even, Daenerys might view Sansa and the other Starks as threats to Jon.

From an outsider perspective (maybe even Tyrion and Jorah), there might be speculation that the legitimate Stark children are angry and upset with Jon – “he took Winterfell from under their nose and then gave it away.”

Other siblings have killed one another for their family’s seat of power.

Perhaps, Tyrion or Jorah might want to separate Dany from Jon, possibly hinting at her siding with the Legitimate Stark Children in this “battle for Winterfell.”

But the Starks aren’t like other families, as we’ve been shown. The pack stays together and that pack include Jon. As we kind of see with the few seconds we got (and past seasons), Jon is no longer the outsider in Winterfell.

Basically, I think Daenerys for at least the first episode will be in a fragile and politically tense setting, where everyone might be in it for themselves and I am curious to see how she deals with it.

For instance, Jorah sees Daenerys as being the best thing for Westeros. While I imagine Varys might strongly disagree, given his scenes form the previous season.  

Overall, this will be a new situation for Dany. Working with people who aren’t your enemy, but aren’t necessarily on your side either. Working with people who you don’t like and who don’t like you for a cause greater than yourself.

And I stress, the whole greater than yourself.

And who you also have to win over, without your dragons, as you currently want to be their queen and “sister-in-law.”

Honestly, I am pretty excited to see Daenerys’ patience running out and seeing people make excuses for her.

I want all the drama.

Overall, this will be a new situation for Dany. Working with people who aren’t your enemy, but aren’t necessarily on your side either. Working with people who you don’t like and who don’t like you for a cause greater than yourself.

And I stress, the whole greater than yourself.

And who you also have to win over, without your dragons, as you currently want to be their queen and “sister-in-law.”

Honestly, I am pretty excited to see Daenerys’ patience running out and seeing people make excuses for her.

I want all the drama.

trail.content_raw:
“She’s now in a very unfamiliar situation in that she cannot just threaten people into submission because she’s infatuated with Jon and wants him to like her. She has to play a game of courtesy, which was never her strong suit… As her dragons and armies grew, she never had the need to be a diplomat and be polite to the people she negotiated with because she had all the hard power and she wasn’t averse to using it.”

A small fraction of @trinuviel‘s breakdown of Daenery’s outfit in the teaser and what it represents. Read Here 

This aspect of Dany’s journey is very interesting to me.

[[MORE]]

As she’s hasn’t really had to play the long game of politics or “playing nice” with others, especially with those she doesn’t like. And it might be hard to see that as a flaw of hers.

In the past seasons, we’ve like that about Daenerys. We also like that about Jon Snow, Arya Stark, Ned Stark and Olenna Tyrell – cutting through the bullshit with blunt honesty. Being direct and concise and not playing the stupid and pointless political games.

These characters are often performing a wish-fulfillment for the audience, we would love to tell off other people who are clearly not doing what they should be doing and just cut through all the fake-smiles. 

Especially if you work in the service industry. 

Or sometimes the character does what we want to see happen in our own real-world politics.

It’s not exactly a bad trait, but it’s also certainly not a good one (honestly, it depends on the situation).

Daenerys not really knowing how to or I would argue, not really having the patience for the long game, isn’t a strength of hers, though. And personally, I see that as more of a flaw.

In life, you have to play nice. 

And in the world of Westeros, you have to play the political game. You don’t have to fight for the Iron Throne like Cersei (and Dany and others think), but you are part of the overall scheme.

And this is also where the difference between Conquerors and Queens/Kings comes into play. You have to get people on your side and currently when there are multiple “heirs” for the Iron Throne, that’s more important than ever.

You want people to want you on the Throne. And no major groups of people in Westeros actively want Daenerys on the Throne. They also don’t want Cersei, but if your best-selling point is that you might be slightly better than Cersei Lannister…well, good luck with that.

A conqueror or tyrant threatens and uses hard or violent power and while a King/Queen can also do that, arguably that leaves more of a bad impression and an even worse taste in one’s mouth. 

Cersei is not a good queen for blowing up the Sept. Joffrey was not a good king for hurting Sansa. And King Aerys II was not a good king for torturing and killing his subjects.

Bad blood begins to spill over – 2 out of 3, so far, have been killed by those they ‘trusted’ or at least would never suspect.

Dany should’ve learned from Meereen – conquering and ruling are two very different beasts. One can be done in an “instant” and the other is never truly done, you will always have to work – if you are to be a good ruler or leader.

And Dany lacks that patience.

So, depending on how long the political drama/game goes on between Daenerys and the Starks, I am interested to see how Dany handles it.

I personally believe, Daenerys will get frustrated with Sansa. Who I think will never be open or exactly warm to her, but always courteous and polite. Which yeah, that would be frustrating from Dany’s POV, but you have to still grin and bear it. 

Or maybe even, Daenerys might view Sansa and the other Starks as threats to Jon.

From an outsider perspective (maybe even Tyrion and Jorah), there might be speculation that the legitimate Stark children are angry and upset with Jon – “he took Winterfell from under their nose and then gave it away.”

Other siblings have killed one another for their family’s seat of power.

Perhaps, Tyrion or Jorah might want to separate Dany from Jon, possibly hinting at her siding with the Legitimate Stark Children in this “battle for Winterfell.”

But the Starks aren’t like other families, as we’ve been shown. The pack stays together and that pack include Jon. As we kind of see with the few seconds we got (and past seasons), Jon is no longer the outsider in Winterfell.

Basically, I think Daenerys for at least the first episode will be in a fragile and politically tense setting, where everyone might be in it for themselves and I am curious to see how she deals with it.

For instance, Jorah sees Daenerys as being the best thing for Westeros. While I imagine Varys might strongly disagree, given his scenes form the previous season.  

Overall, this will be a new situation for Dany. Working with people who aren’t your enemy, but aren’t necessarily on your side either. Working with people who you don’t like and who don’t like you for a cause greater than yourself.

And I stress, the whole greater than yourself.

And who you also have to win over, without your dragons, as you currently want to be their queen and “sister-in-law.”

Honestly, I am pretty excited to see Daenerys’ patience running out and seeing people make excuses for her.

I want all the drama.

title: A Lady’s Armor: Part 2
body:
That seemed to anger him. “You hide behind courtesy as if it were a castle wall.”

“Courtesy is a lady’s armor,” Sansa said. Her septa had always told her that.

- Sansa III, ASOS

As has been discussed before, all the main female characters in season 7 have symbolic armor represented in their clothing, but the phrases that Clapton calls attention to are the ones that count. And only when they’re seen as a whole and in comparison to the other characters she wants you to compare them with, that one finds more clarity in her venture as she considers costume designing as a form of storytelling. 

“I don’t think any costume should be looked at in isolation, rather, through the arc of the character. Each thing will tell a story. It might look like a costume is wrong, but actually it’s supposed to look like that. It’s telling you something about the character at the time.” (Winter is Coming)

In Sansa’s case, Clapton kept bringing up phrases like “binding her against vulnerability”, “encased in her costume”, “tightly laced”, “sewn or laced into her costume”, “no way in”, “no one will get to me again”, “absolute removal of any possible physical touch”, “controlled”, etc. A lot of it was influenced by the inclusion of the belt and criss cross leather straps around her, but that is a fundamental piece to consider while analysing Sansa’s costumes and her character, and every other part is contextualised by it. 

In Part 1, I discussed characters and other costumes who Sansa’s season 7 costume’s silhouette was influenced by in order to understand Clapton’s phrases. In this part, I will be discussing the contrasting textures that make this armor-like silhouette.   

Textures and Quilting

”Within each of their costumes, there are influences. […] Sansa’s are part father, part mother. It’s her father’s silhouette with the fur, her mother’s within. The textures are very much from her mother.”  - Michele Clapton, Elle

“The cut of the costume was very fitted and severe but the fabrics were soft, textured and quilted. I was trying to grasp all that has happened to Sansa, all the hurt and abuse and frustration, and trying to understand how she would express this yet appear strong. She adapts all she has learnt to her look.” - Michele Clapton to HuffPost

Although, the severe cuts are to show a sense of hardening in the time of winter and the lords overlooking her because of her gender, Sansa still finds ways to express herself through how she uses her textures as pointed out in the last post, that needlework is heavily tied to Sansa’s connection to her mother showwise. Unlike Cersei, she moves away from beading as winter has come and rather takes to using quilting to express herself and also to cover up her seams. 

The dresses are quilted with padding for protection against coid winter despite the armor like cuts. The materials she uses are either her recycling what she had before or merely working with textures of simple fabric and patterns in a limited way. It shows frugality considering the point in time, while also not taking away Sansa’s connection to the sewing needle altogether. In Sansa’s case, the act of sewing is a very intimate affair because it’s a way of her remembering her mother, Septa Mordane and her childhood. 

“I wanted a real strength,” Clapton says. “I think that she’s embraced everything that’s happened to her.” The designer chose to adorn Sansa with a heavy belt that wraps around her neck and goes to her waistline, covering a double-breasted dress.“It’s almost like ‘no one will ever get to me again,’” Clapton says. “There’s an armor to her. There’s feathers again from her time in the Eyrie. There’s a circular necklace, which I think is really important with a needlepoint. And there’s an element in the dress of her mother, the pattern is almost like fishes swimming. It’s this binding against her vulnerability. It’s full of symbolism.” - Clapton to UpRoxx 

There are essentially three dresses with varying quilting details that Sansa wears during the course of the season,but they can be mistaken for one of the other because of their similar structure. Sansa wears these dresses either on their own or with the cloak except for the third, which she always wears with a shoulder fur, even when not with a cloak. 

Interestingly, the fabric of all three is similar, but the quilting of the Eyrie dress especially makes it seem like it is made out of a thicker material that almost resembles Dany’s winter cloak. But if you look closely, it’s similar to Northern fabrics used before.

It has textures of the roughspun Northern dresses we’ve seen before. It’s not fine material like silks but it’s still comfortable and is functional in keeping warm. It’s also quilted and provided with a soft padding underneath and probably lined inside with wool. The other fabrics and textures, which include feathers, patchwork or thread work, are sewn onto the costumes to form the geometrical patterns.

Dress #1: The Eyrie feathers

The feathers on this dress are from the Eyrie dress that was used in season 4 and 5.

It references her alliance with the Vale, but doesn’t stop at that. The presence of armor is most pronounced by this dress because of its stark suppression of sexuality with the strips of Eyrie feathers covering the exposed section of her cleavage and going up to her neck, where she wears a high collar, and tapering down to her waist.

The strips the feathers are placed on are straight rather than curved and because of this reassembling from afar they could resemble scales and thus appear less gentle. In fact, the Tully armor has scales like this. Though the silhouette is completely different.  

Additionally, the feathers in that dress evolve into shoulder tabs resembling Northern armor pieces or furs and the feathers surrounding the back come up in the Northern women collar piece. Instead of embroidery around it, the symbolic significance is sized down to the use of these feathers on it topped with metallic direwolves on its ends.  

What’s also interesting about it is how it seems to be recycling patches from the previous dress such that the edges are rough as she places one top of the other like plates. It’s not as finely done as her Eyrie dress. She also uses vertical lines to quilt the dress. 

Overall, the way it is refashioned its silhouette resembles the Night’s Watch training armor. And of course, the brothers of the Night’s Watch are known as “crows”, who are quite closely related to ravens.

Thus, she’s bringing all parts of her journey together.

Interestingly, unlike the Eyrie dress and the Night’s Watch armor, Sansa’s dress is grey, although it looks almost like black in poor lighting. This dress isn’t for anyone’s benefit like the Eyrie dress was.

Where the season 4 “raven dress” was meant entice, her season 7 version of the Eyrie feathers is meant to shield her from the male gaze. It still sends a “message” nonetheless. Not only to keep those who want to violate her body away from her, but also in a way to appeal to a patriarchal society that she has more worth than just her body. 

Still there is a kind of juxtaposition between the structure of the dress as it has bird feathers, which follow Sansa’s winged imagery through seasons, but the way it is arranged in straight lines it is a lot more constrained. She’s confined in it as much as it acts as an armor.

Dress #2: Criss Cross Pattern

While it isn’t obvious because of the poor lighting, not only does Sansa wear this with her cloak and furs but also she wears it in the scene where Jon gives the North to her in 7x02. The criss cross pattern isn’t just a print but rather made from placing strips of different cloths on top of each other like patchwork. Thereby it’s a lot more textured. When not wearing furs, she pairs it up with the Northern woman’s collar with two metallic direwolves lined with raven feathers from her Eyrie dress.  

The pattern on the dress could be the central rhombus on the Northern leather armor with finer lines. Or it could also be a minimalist fish swimming vertically. 

Considering the scene in 7x03 is where she’s talking about layering the armors to protect the soldiers from the cold, it’s most likely an armor pattern. There’s also the fact that the other dress is explicitly acknowledged to be inspired by Catelyn’s Tully side. Additionally, given there is one Vale and Night’s Watch influenced dress and one Tully influenced dress, this one is more influenced by the North in its details.

Still, Sansa’s costumes often have dual quality, so I could see how the checkered pattern could be seen as fish scales. Perhaps, even the narrow diagonal lines on the side are partly influenced by Brienne’s armor as well. Also considering Clapton seems to be focusing on Sansa’s “tight lacing”, the lines could be seen as laces she is tying herself tighter with.

Dress #3: Fishes Swimming Pattern

Strangely, Sansa never wears this dress without a shoulder fur, even when she leaves her cloak in 7x05. However, the dress without with its furs has been displayed at the FIDM Museum.

Interviewer: Is Sansa’s fabric one of the furnishing fabrics?

Clapton: I think it is – it might be the reverse side. I thought it looked like fishes swimming. I think we worked into it a bit – it’s beautiful. We found some great fabrics that year, and this year we struggled to find such great things so we had to do a lot more work within the actual fabric. But it’s so interesting when you boil something and manipulate it – I love doing that!

A number of people hypothesised that the pattern was the Bolton sigil but on close look, it does look like fishes swimming upstream and downstream, where their heads and tails are in white/light grey. 

It’s worth noting that compared to the other two dresses, the use of line is a lot more fluid considering the they curve to form streamlined fish bodies and even the quilting uses narrower vertical lines. Hence this outfit also looks a bit more traditionally feminine. 

That said, since this costume does have a lot of lacing significance to “bind” herself, the lines do look like threads and they could be seen as nets too and the tight lacing of the belt and leather straps around her body also cut the fluid appearance of the fishes, giving the dress a dual quality of empowerment and entrapment.

Some may have noticed how Sansa’s movements in this dress without a cloak looked a bit stiff and awkward. It may have been intentional considering Clapton’s theme with her character this season as pointed out in the last post. This tight lacing isn’t meant to be comfortable. Additionally, in order to mask the side opening of the dress, she uses quilting with narrower strips of the same material so it’s hard to tell apart one layer from the other.

Apart from this, Sansa wears her wide hard leather belt and straps around her body and loops her metallic necklace with the circle and needle around her borrowed from her Eyrie raven-like costume. These two elements seal the battle iconography ultimately, where one is an armor and the other is a weapon in the making. The metal stands out against the rest of her rather close fitted costume, but it’s also in response to the Doylist comparison being cued amongst Sansa, Dany and Cersei in how they’re using jewellery. 

The use of armor isn’t altogether new. She has been building her armor since Ned’s death. It prominently features in her two wedding dresses.

The rigidity of the shape is quite telling of her state and mindset. They essentially “encase” her as well and in that way appear like a shell around her. 

“For Sansa’s wedding dress the designer Michele Clapton wanted to have an embroidered band that wrapped around which symbolistically told Sansa’s life from the Tully and Stark beginnings to the entanglement with the Lannisters. Her story starts at her lower back where the Tully fish and Stark Direwolf entwine as we move round to the front the Lannister Lion is becoming dominant over the Direwolf and at the back neck the Lions head is stamped onto Sansa. The dress colour was still very much Sansa Stark and the embroidery had pale golden tones but woven through the story are ripe red pomegranates, the red colour symbolising the growing Lannister influence over her.” - Michele Carraghar

As I’ve also written before, these dresses parallel or make references to Lyanna. The additional appendage with embroidery around it is like Lyanna’s metallic brace at her wedding to Rhaegar. But there is more to it as Sansa’s season 3 wedding dress is not made by her but rather the Lannisters. 

“Obviously we imagined that the wedding dress has been commissioned by Cersei and the Lannisters for Sansa, and so the embroidery would have come from Cersei’s mind. We guessed that it wouldn’t be romantic or lovely and girly and pretty with dainty flowers, but a real strong message of dominance, saying that we own you now, Sansa.”

“Wedding days should be a joyous event for the bride, but, unfortunately, Sansa’s being forced into a marriage that she doesn’t want, into the Lannister family. For this dress, Michelle wanted it to be a confined, restricted bodice shape with bare, vulnerable arms. She wanted an embroidered band that would wrap around the bodice and tell Sansa’s life story.” - Michele Carragher to SCPR

So if it looks like an armor, it’s still her being forced into it and it is another form of abuse in its own way. It’s a cage. But it’s not that she won’t use some of it in the future by subverting it into her favour. 

According to Clapton Sansa does end up designing her second wedding dress paying respects to her family because it’s about her goal to take back her family home. 

“What struck me about Sansa’s wedding gown is that (much like Margaery’s second wedding gown) this one was wholly Sansa. Clapton says that was deliberate. “It’s Sansa trying to respect everyone that’s been before her. She finally feels like she can make Winterfell a family home again. So I wanted to incorporate pieces that represented her family.” There’s the animal fur of the wolf that also recalls the furs we saw Ned and Robb sport in earlier seasons. There’s the shape of the dress, which is very northern, and one her mother wore frequently. There’s the fish shaped closures, which represent her Tully heritage.” - Winteriscoming

At this point in time, it’s not about romantic ideals so her dress still takes on a defensive structure. While she wears Northern attire like her mother’s, the rigidity of the structure is very stone-like and was inspired by the figures in the crypts and with her hair done up as if roses are in her hair, it alludes to Lyanna. 

“The shape was also engineered to look a bit like the statues in the crypt at Winterfell.” - Fashionista

The restrictive structure conveys how this wedding is yet another battlefield for Sansa, not a wedding she genuinely wants to enter. Oddly despite its rigid silhouette, the textures on it again are very gentle like the dress that is quilted with miniature patterns of wings playing into her bird/dragonfly iconography and the white fur on her back shaped like two wings from her back. There’s no beading here. While Sansa does pay respects to her family, this isn’t a wedding she wants to be at either and it is essentially driven by her desire to avenge her family that Littlefinger manipulates her into doing by convincing her she would be weak otherwise. As we know, what follows is that dress being ripped apart by the “wings” by Ramsay and she is abused further. 

So the phrase “as if she was actually sewn or laced into her dress—like there was no way in” is in response to that and her abuse and exploitation by the Lannisters and Littlefinger and her betrayals by others as well. It results in her sewing every layer into the other so they can almost merge into one another - even when it is made to appear hardened. She doesn’t just want a shell as a protective layer, she tries to sew herself into the shell so it’s impossible to remove. 

That kind of imagery sounds painful and quite tragic when you think of it. As powerful as this sounds in terms of her abusers, there’s a vulnerability in Sansa not wanting anyone to touch her or break through her walls. She’s afraid of believing in anyone and trusting them with her life completely again after being burned so many times. 

(to be continued…)

A/N: In the next part, I will compare Sansa’s textures with Cersei’s and Dany’s - including the significance of jewellery and perhaps in the one that follows, I’ll go back to comparing the remaining parts of their silhouettes. I was going to include the former in this post but the new footage just came with a lot more material and I didn’t want to make these posts too long since it hampers readability and it’s asking a lot of people’s attention span.

“Courtesy is a lady’s armor,” Sansa said. Her septa had always told her that.

- Sansa III, ASOS

As has been discussed before, all the main female characters in season 7 have symbolic armor represented in their clothing, but the phrases that Clapton calls attention to are the ones that count. And only when they’re seen as a whole and in comparison to the other characters she wants you to compare them with, that one finds more clarity in her venture as she considers costume designing as a form of storytelling. 

“I don’t think any costume should be looked at in isolation, rather, through the arc of the character. Each thing will tell a story. It might look like a costume is wrong, but actually it’s supposed to look like that. It’s telling you something about the character at the time.” (Winter is Coming)

In Sansa’s case, Clapton kept bringing up phrases like “binding her against vulnerability”, “encased in her costume”, “tightly laced”, “sewn or laced into her costume”, “no way in”, “no one will get to me again”, “absolute removal of any possible physical touch”, “controlled”, etc. A lot of it was influenced by the inclusion of the belt and criss cross leather straps around her, but that is a fundamental piece to consider while analysing Sansa’s costumes and her character, and every other part is contextualised by it. 

In Part 1, I discussed characters and other costumes who Sansa’s season 7 costume’s silhouette was influenced by in order to understand Clapton’s phrases. In this part, I will be discussing the contrasting textures that make this armor-like silhouette.   

Textures and Quilting

”Within each of their costumes, there are influences. […] Sansa’s are part father, part mother. It’s her father’s silhouette with the fur, her mother’s within. The textures are very much from her mother.”  - Michele Clapton, Elle

“The cut of the costume was very fitted and severe but the fabrics were soft, textured and quilted. I was trying to grasp all that has happened to Sansa, all the hurt and abuse and frustration, and trying to understand how she would express this yet appear strong. She adapts all she has learnt to her look.” - Michele Clapton to HuffPost

Although, the severe cuts are to show a sense of hardening in the time of winter and the lords overlooking her because of her gender, Sansa still finds ways to express herself through how she uses her textures as pointed out in the last post, that needlework is heavily tied to Sansa’s connection to her mother showwise. Unlike Cersei, she moves away from beading as winter has come and rather takes to using quilting to express herself and also to cover up her seams. 

The dresses are quilted with padding for protection against coid winter despite the armor like cuts. The materials she uses are either her recycling what she had before or merely working with textures of simple fabric and patterns in a limited way. It shows frugality considering the point in time, while also not taking away Sansa’s connection to the sewing needle altogether. In Sansa’s case, the act of sewing is a very intimate affair because it’s a way of her remembering her mother, Septa Mordane and her childhood.

It shows frugality considering the point in time, while also not taking away Sansa’s connection to the sewing needle altogether. In Sansa’s case, the act of sewing is a very intimate affair because it’s a way of her remembering her mother, Septa Mordane and her childhood. 

[[MORE]]

“I wanted a real strength,” Clapton says. “I think that she’s embraced everything that’s happened to her.” The designer chose to adorn Sansa with a heavy belt that wraps around her neck and goes to her waistline, covering a double-breasted dress.“It’s almost like ‘no one will ever get to me again,’” Clapton says. “There’s an armor to her. There’s feathers again from her time in the Eyrie. There’s a circular necklace, which I think is really important with a needlepoint. And there’s an element in the dress of her mother, the pattern is almost like fishes swimming. It’s this binding against her vulnerability. It’s full of symbolism.” - Clapton to UpRoxx 

There are essentially three dresses with varying quilting details that Sansa wears during the course of the season,but they can be mistaken for one of the other because of their similar structure. Sansa wears these dresses either on their own or with the cloak except for the third, which she always wears with a shoulder fur, even when not with a cloak. 

Interestingly, the fabric of all three is similar, but the quilting of the Eyrie dress especially makes it seem like it is made out of a thicker material that almost resembles Dany’s winter cloak. But if you look closely, it’s similar to Northern fabrics used before.

It has textures of the roughspun Northern dresses we’ve seen before. It’s not fine material like silks but it’s still comfortable and is functional in keeping warm. It’s also quilted and provided with a soft padding underneath and probably lined inside with wool. The other fabrics and textures, which include feathers, patchwork or thread work, are sewn onto the costumes to form the geometrical patterns.

Dress #1: The Eyrie feathers

The feathers on this dress are from the Eyrie dress that was used in season 4 and 5.

It references her alliance with the Vale, but doesn’t stop at that. The presence of armor is most pronounced by this dress because of its stark suppression of sexuality with the strips of Eyrie feathers covering the exposed section of her cleavage and going up to her neck, where she wears a high collar, and tapering down to her waist.

The strips the feathers are placed on are straight rather than curved and because of this reassembling from afar they could resemble scales and thus appear less gentle. In fact, the Tully armor has scales like this. Though the silhouette is completely different.  

Additionally, the feathers in that dress evolve into shoulder tabs resembling Northern armor pieces or furs and the feathers surrounding the back come up in the Northern women collar piece. Instead of embroidery around it, the symbolic significance is sized down to the use of these feathers on it topped with metallic direwolves on its ends.  

What’s also interesting about it is how it seems to be recycling patches from the previous dress such that the edges are rough as she places one top of the other like plates. It’s not as finely done as her Eyrie dress. She also uses vertical lines to quilt the dress. 

Overall, the way it is refashioned its silhouette resembles the Night’s Watch training armor. And of course, the brothers of the Night’s Watch are known as “crows”, who are quite closely related to ravens.

Thus, she’s bringing all parts of her journey together.

Interestingly, unlike the Eyrie dress and the Night’s Watch armor, Sansa’s dress is grey, although it looks almost like black in poor lighting. This dress isn’t for anyone’s benefit like the Eyrie dress was.

Where the season 4 “raven dress” was meant entice, her season 7 version of the Eyrie feathers is meant to shield her from the male gaze. It still sends a “message” nonetheless. Not only to keep those who want to violate her body away from her, but also in a way to appeal to a patriarchal society that she has more worth than just her body. 

Still there is a kind of juxtaposition between the structure of the dress as it has bird feathers, which follow Sansa’s winged imagery through seasons, but the way it is arranged in straight lines it is a lot more constrained. She’s confined in it as much as it acts as an armor.

Dress #2: Criss Cross Pattern

While it isn’t obvious because of the poor lighting, not only does Sansa wear this with her cloak and furs but also she wears it in the scene where Jon gives the North to her in 7x02. The criss cross pattern isn’t just a print but rather made from placing strips of different cloths on top of each other like patchwork. Thereby it’s a lot more textured. When not wearing furs, she pairs it up with the Northern woman’s collar with two metallic direwolves lined with raven feathers from her Eyrie dress.  

The pattern on the dress could be the central rhombus on the Northern leather armor with finer lines. Or it could also be a minimalist fish swimming vertically. 

Considering the scene in 7x03 is where she’s talking about layering the armors to protect the soldiers from the cold, it’s most likely an armor pattern. There’s also the fact that the other dress is explicitly acknowledged to be inspired by Catelyn’s Tully side. Additionally, given there is one Vale and Night’s Watch influenced dress and one Tully influenced dress, this one is more influenced by the North in its details.

Still, Sansa’s costumes often have dual quality, so I could see how the checkered pattern could be seen as fish scales. Perhaps, even the narrow diagonal lines on the side are partly influenced by Brienne’s armor as well. Also considering Clapton seems to be focusing on Sansa’s “tight lacing”, the lines could be seen as laces she is tying herself tighter with.

Dress #3: Fishes Swimming Pattern

Strangely, Sansa never wears this dress without a shoulder fur, even when she leaves her cloak in 7x05. However, the dress without with its furs has been displayed at the FIDM Museum.

Interviewer: Is Sansa’s fabric one of the furnishing fabrics?

Clapton: I think it is – it might be the reverse side. I thought it looked like fishes swimming. I think we worked into it a bit – it’s beautiful. We found some great fabrics that year, and this year we struggled to find such great things so we had to do a lot more work within the actual fabric. But it’s so interesting when you boil something and manipulate it – I love doing that!

A number of people hypothesised that the pattern was the Bolton sigil but on close look, it does look like fishes swimming upstream and downstream, where their heads and tails are in white/light grey. 

It’s worth noting that compared to the other two dresses, the use of line is a lot more fluid considering the they curve to form streamlined fish bodies and even the quilting uses narrower vertical lines. Hence this outfit also looks a bit more traditionally feminine. 

That said, since this costume does have a lot of lacing significance to “bind” herself, the lines do look like threads and they could be seen as nets too and the tight lacing of the belt and leather straps around her body also cut the fluid appearance of the fishes, giving the dress a dual quality of empowerment and entrapment.

Some may have noticed how Sansa’s movements in this dress without a cloak looked a bit stiff and awkward. It may have been intentional considering Clapton’s theme with her character this season as pointed out in the last post. This tight lacing isn’t meant to be comfortable. Additionally, in order to mask the side opening of the dress, she uses quilting with narrower strips of the same material so it’s hard to tell apart one layer from the other.

Apart from this, Sansa wears her wide hard leather belt and straps around her body and loops her metallic necklace with the circle and needle around her borrowed from her Eyrie raven-like costume. These two elements seal the battle iconography ultimately, where one is an armor and the other is a weapon in the making. The metal stands out against the rest of her rather close fitted costume, but it’s also in response to the Doylist comparison being cued amongst Sansa, Dany and Cersei in how they’re using jewellery. 

The use of armor isn’t altogether new. She has been building her armor since Ned’s death. It prominently features in her two wedding dresses.

The rigidity of the shape is quite telling of her state and mindset. They essentially “encase” her as well and in that way appear like a shell around her. 

“For Sansa’s wedding dress the designer Michele Clapton wanted to have an embroidered band that wrapped around which symbolistically told Sansa’s life from the Tully and Stark beginnings to the entanglement with the Lannisters. Her story starts at her lower back where the Tully fish and Stark Direwolf entwine as we move round to the front the Lannister Lion is becoming dominant over the Direwolf and at the back neck the Lions head is stamped onto Sansa. The dress colour was still very much Sansa Stark and the embroidery had pale golden tones but woven through the story are ripe red pomegranates, the red colour symbolising the growing Lannister influence over her.” - Michele Carraghar

As I’ve also written before, these dresses parallel or make references to Lyanna. The additional appendage with embroidery around it is like Lyanna’s metallic brace at her wedding to Rhaegar. But there is more to it as Sansa’s season 3 wedding dress is not made by her but rather the Lannisters. 

“Obviously we imagined that the wedding dress has been commissioned by Cersei and the Lannisters for Sansa, and so the embroidery would have come from Cersei’s mind. We guessed that it wouldn’t be romantic or lovely and girly and pretty with dainty flowers, but a real strong message of dominance, saying that we own you now, Sansa.”

“Wedding days should be a joyous event for the bride, but, unfortunately, Sansa’s being forced into a marriage that she doesn’t want, into the Lannister family. For this dress, Michelle wanted it to be a confined, restricted bodice shape with bare, vulnerable arms. She wanted an embroidered band that would wrap around the bodice and tell Sansa’s life story.” - Michele Carragher to SCPR

So if it looks like an armor, it’s still her being forced into it and it is another form of abuse in its own way. It’s a cage. But it’s not that she won’t use some of it in the future by subverting it into her favour. 

According to Clapton Sansa does end up designing her second wedding dress paying respects to her family because it’s about her goal to take back her family home. 

“What struck me about Sansa’s wedding gown is that (much like Margaery’s second wedding gown) this one was wholly Sansa. Clapton says that was deliberate. “It’s Sansa trying to respect everyone that’s been before her. She finally feels like she can make Winterfell a family home again. So I wanted to incorporate pieces that represented her family.” There’s the animal fur of the wolf that also recalls the furs we saw Ned and Robb sport in earlier seasons. There’s the shape of the dress, which is very northern, and one her mother wore frequently. There’s the fish shaped closures, which represent her Tully heritage.” - Winteriscoming

At this point in time, it’s not about romantic ideals so her dress still takes on a defensive structure. While she wears Northern attire like her mother’s, the rigidity of the structure is very stone-like and was inspired by the figures in the crypts and with her hair done up as if roses are in her hair, it alludes to Lyanna. 

“The shape was also engineered to look a bit like the statues in the crypt at Winterfell.” - Fashionista

The restrictive structure conveys how this wedding is yet another battlefield for Sansa, not a wedding she genuinely wants to enter. Oddly despite its rigid silhouette, the textures on it again are very gentle like the dress that is quilted with miniature patterns of wings playing into her bird/dragonfly iconography and the white fur on her back shaped like two wings from her back. There’s no beading here. While Sansa does pay respects to her family, this isn’t a wedding she wants to be at either and it is essentially driven by her desire to avenge her family that Littlefinger manipulates her into doing by convincing her she would be weak otherwise. As we know, what follows is that dress being ripped apart by the “wings” by Ramsay and she is abused further. 

So the phrase “as if she was actually sewn or laced into her dress—like there was no way in” is in response to that and her abuse and exploitation by the Lannisters and Littlefinger and her betrayals by others as well. It results in her sewing every layer into the other so they can almost merge into one another - even when it is made to appear hardened. She doesn’t just want a shell as a protective layer, she tries to sew herself into the shell so it’s impossible to remove. 

That kind of imagery sounds painful and quite tragic when you think of it. As powerful as this sounds in terms of her abusers, there’s a vulnerability in Sansa not wanting anyone to touch her or break through her walls. She’s afraid of believing in anyone and trusting them with her life completely again after being burned so many times. 

(to be continued…)

A/N: In the next part, I will compare Sansa’s textures with Cersei’s and Dany’s - including the significance of jewellery and perhaps in the one that follows, I’ll go back to comparing the remaining parts of their silhouettes. I was going to include the former in this post but the new footage just came with a lot more material and I didn’t want to make these posts too long since it hampers readability and it’s asking a lot of people’s attention span.

Clapton says that was deliberate. “It’s Sansa trying to respect everyone that’s been before her. She finally feels like she can make Winterfell a family home again. So I wanted to incorporate pieces that represented her family.” There’s the animal fur of the wolf that also recalls the furs we saw Ned and Robb sport in earlier seasons. There’s the shape of the dress, which is very northern, and one her mother wore frequently. There’s the fish shaped closures, which represent her Tully heritage.” - Winteriscoming

At this point in time, it’s not about romantic ideals so her dress still takes on a defensive structure. While she wears Northern attire like her mother’s, the rigidity of the structure is very stone-like and was inspired by the figures in the crypts and with her hair done up as if roses are in her hair, it alludes to Lyanna. 

“The shape was also engineered to look a bit like the statues in the crypt at Winterfell.” - Fashionista

The restrictive structure conveys how this wedding is yet another battlefield for Sansa, not a wedding she genuinely wants to enter. Oddly despite its rigid silhouette, the textures on it again are very gentle like the dress that is quilted with miniature patterns of wings playing into her bird/dragonfly iconography and the white fur on her back shaped like two wings from her back. There’s no beading here. While Sansa does pay respects to her family, this isn’t a wedding she wants to be at either and it is essentially driven by her desire to avenge her family that Littlefinger manipulates her into doing by convincing her she would be weak otherwise. As we know, what follows is that dress being ripped apart by the “wings” by Ramsay and she is abused further. 

So the phrase “as if she was actually sewn or laced into her dress—like there was no way in” is in response to that and her abuse and exploitation by the Lannisters and Littlefinger and her betrayals by others as well. It results in her sewing every layer into the other so they can almost merge into one another - even when it is made to appear hardened. She doesn’t just want a shell as a protective layer, she tries to sew herself into the shell so it’s impossible to remove. 

That kind of imagery sounds painful and quite tragic when you think of it. As powerful as this sounds in terms of her abusers, there’s a vulnerability in Sansa not wanting anyone to touch her or break through her walls. She’s afraid of believing in anyone and trusting them with her life completely again after being burned so many times. 

(to be continued…)

I was going to include the former in this post but the new footage just came with a lot more material and I didn’t want to make these posts too long since it hampers readability and it’s asking a lot of people’s attention span.
trail.content:
That seemed to anger him. “You hide behind courtesy as if it were a castle wall.”

“Courtesy is a lady’s armor,” Sansa said. Her septa had always told her that.

- Sansa III, ASOS

As has been discussed before, all the main female characters in season 7 have symbolic armor represented in their clothing, but the phrases that Clapton calls attention to are the ones that count. And only when they’re seen as a whole and in comparison to the other characters she wants you to compare them with, that one finds more clarity in her venture as she considers costume designing as a form of storytelling. 

“I don’t think any costume should be looked at in isolation, rather, through the arc of the character. Each thing will tell a story. It might look like a costume is wrong, but actually it’s supposed to look like that. It’s telling you something about the character at the time.” (Winter is Coming)

In Sansa’s case, Clapton kept bringing up phrases like “binding her against vulnerability”, “encased in her costume”, “tightly laced”, “sewn or laced into her costume”, “no way in”, “no one will get to me again”, “absolute removal of any possible physical touch”, “controlled”, etc. A lot of it was influenced by the inclusion of the belt and criss cross leather straps around her, but that is a fundamental piece to consider while analysing Sansa’s costumes and her character, and every other part is contextualised by it. 

In Part 1, I discussed characters and other costumes who Sansa’s season 7 costume’s silhouette was influenced by in order to understand Clapton’s phrases. In this part, I will be discussing the contrasting textures that make this armor-like silhouette.   

Textures and Quilting

”Within each of their costumes, there are influences. […] Sansa’s are part father, part mother. It’s her father’s silhouette with the fur, her mother’s within. The textures are very much from her mother.”  - Michele Clapton, Elle

“The cut of the costume was very fitted and severe but the fabrics were soft, textured and quilted. I was trying to grasp all that has happened to Sansa, all the hurt and abuse and frustration, and trying to understand how she would express this yet appear strong. She adapts all she has learnt to her look.” - Michele Clapton to HuffPost

Although, the severe cuts are to show a sense of hardening in the time of winter and the lords overlooking her because of her gender, Sansa still finds ways to express herself through how she uses her textures as pointed out in the last post, that needlework is heavily tied to Sansa’s connection to her mother showwise. Unlike Cersei, she moves away from beading as winter has come and rather takes to using quilting to express herself and also to cover up her seams. 

The dresses are quilted with padding for protection against coid winter despite the armor like cuts. The materials she uses are either her recycling what she had before or merely working with textures of simple fabric and patterns in a limited way. It shows frugality considering the point in time, while also not taking away Sansa’s connection to the sewing needle altogether. In Sansa’s case, the act of sewing is a very intimate affair because it’s a way of her remembering her mother, Septa Mordane and her childhood. 

“I wanted a real strength,” Clapton says. “I think that she’s embraced everything that’s happened to her.” The designer chose to adorn Sansa with a heavy belt that wraps around her neck and goes to her waistline, covering a double-breasted dress.“It’s almost like ‘no one will ever get to me again,’” Clapton says. “There’s an armor to her. There’s feathers again from her time in the Eyrie. There’s a circular necklace, which I think is really important with a needlepoint. And there’s an element in the dress of her mother, the pattern is almost like fishes swimming. It’s this binding against her vulnerability. It’s full of symbolism.” - Clapton to UpRoxx 

There are essentially three dresses with varying quilting details that Sansa wears during the course of the season,but they can be mistaken for one of the other because of their similar structure. Sansa wears these dresses either on their own or with the cloak except for the third, which she always wears with a shoulder fur, even when not with a cloak. 

Interestingly, the fabric of all three is similar, but the quilting of the Eyrie dress especially makes it seem like it is made out of a thicker material that almost resembles Dany’s winter cloak. But if you look closely, it’s similar to Northern fabrics used before.

It has textures of the roughspun Northern dresses we’ve seen before. It’s not fine material like silks but it’s still comfortable and is functional in keeping warm. It’s also quilted and provided with a soft padding underneath and probably lined inside with wool. The other fabrics and textures, which include feathers, patchwork or thread work, are sewn onto the costumes to form the geometrical patterns.

Dress #1: The Eyrie feathers

The feathers on this dress are from the Eyrie dress that was used in season 4 and 5.

It references her alliance with the Vale, but doesn’t stop at that. The presence of armor is most pronounced by this dress because of its stark suppression of sexuality with the strips of Eyrie feathers covering the exposed section of her cleavage and going up to her neck, where she wears a high collar, and tapering down to her waist.

The strips the feathers are placed on are straight rather than curved and because of this reassembling from afar they could resemble scales and thus appear less gentle. In fact, the Tully armor has scales like this. Though the silhouette is completely different.  

Additionally, the feathers in that dress evolve into shoulder tabs resembling Northern armor pieces or furs and the feathers surrounding the back come up in the Northern women collar piece. Instead of embroidery around it, the symbolic significance is sized down to the use of these feathers on it topped with metallic direwolves on its ends.  

What’s also interesting about it is how it seems to be recycling patches from the previous dress such that the edges are rough as she places one top of the other like plates. It’s not as finely done as her Eyrie dress. She also uses vertical lines to quilt the dress. 

Overall, the way it is refashioned its silhouette resembles the Night’s Watch training armor. And of course, the brothers of the Night’s Watch are known as “crows”, who are quite closely related to ravens.

Thus, she’s bringing all parts of her journey together.

Interestingly, unlike the Eyrie dress and the Night’s Watch armor, Sansa’s dress is grey, although it looks almost like black in poor lighting. This dress isn’t for anyone’s benefit like the Eyrie dress was.

Where the season 4 “raven dress” was meant entice, her season 7 version of the Eyrie feathers is meant to shield her from the male gaze. It still sends a “message” nonetheless. Not only to keep those who want to violate her body away from her, but also in a way to appeal to a patriarchal society that she has more worth than just her body. 

Still there is a kind of juxtaposition between the structure of the dress as it has bird feathers, which follow Sansa’s winged imagery through seasons, but the way it is arranged in straight lines it is a lot more constrained. She’s confined in it as much as it acts as an armor.

Dress #2: Criss Cross Pattern

While it isn’t obvious because of the poor lighting, not only does Sansa wear this with her cloak and furs but also she wears it in the scene where Jon gives the North to her in 7x02. The criss cross pattern isn’t just a print but rather made from placing strips of different cloths on top of each other like patchwork. Thereby it’s a lot more textured. When not wearing furs, she pairs it up with the Northern woman’s collar with two metallic direwolves lined with raven feathers from her Eyrie dress.  

The pattern on the dress could be the central rhombus on the Northern leather armor with finer lines. Or it could also be a minimalist fish swimming vertically. 

Considering the scene in 7x03 is where she’s talking about layering the armors to protect the soldiers from the cold, it’s most likely an armor pattern. There’s also the fact that the other dress is explicitly acknowledged to be inspired by Catelyn’s Tully side. Additionally, given there is one Vale and Night’s Watch influenced dress and one Tully influenced dress, this one is more influenced by the North in its details.

Still, Sansa’s costumes often have dual quality, so I could see how the checkered pattern could be seen as fish scales. Perhaps, even the narrow diagonal lines on the side are partly influenced by Brienne’s armor as well. Also considering Clapton seems to be focusing on Sansa’s “tight lacing”, the lines could be seen as laces she is tying herself tighter with.

Dress #3: Fishes Swimming Pattern

Strangely, Sansa never wears this dress without a shoulder fur, even when she leaves her cloak in 7x05. However, the dress without with its furs has been displayed at the FIDM Museum.

Interviewer: Is Sansa’s fabric one of the furnishing fabrics?

Clapton: I think it is – it might be the reverse side. I thought it looked like fishes swimming. I think we worked into it a bit – it’s beautiful. We found some great fabrics that year, and this year we struggled to find such great things so we had to do a lot more work within the actual fabric. But it’s so interesting when you boil something and manipulate it – I love doing that!

A number of people hypothesised that the pattern was the Bolton sigil but on close look, it does look like fishes swimming upstream and downstream, where their heads and tails are in white/light grey. 

It’s worth noting that compared to the other two dresses, the use of line is a lot more fluid considering the they curve to form streamlined fish bodies and even the quilting uses narrower vertical lines. Hence this outfit also looks a bit more traditionally feminine. 

That said, since this costume does have a lot of lacing significance to “bind” herself, the lines do look like threads and they could be seen as nets too and the tight lacing of the belt and leather straps around her body also cut the fluid appearance of the fishes, giving the dress a dual quality of empowerment and entrapment.

Some may have noticed how Sansa’s movements in this dress without a cloak looked a bit stiff and awkward. It may have been intentional considering Clapton’s theme with her character this season as pointed out in the last post. This tight lacing isn’t meant to be comfortable. Additionally, in order to mask the side opening of the dress, she uses quilting with narrower strips of the same material so it’s hard to tell apart one layer from the other.

Apart from this, Sansa wears her wide hard leather belt and straps around her body and loops her metallic necklace with the circle and needle around her borrowed from her Eyrie raven-like costume. These two elements seal the battle iconography ultimately, where one is an armor and the other is a weapon in the making. The metal stands out against the rest of her rather close fitted costume, but it’s also in response to the Doylist comparison being cued amongst Sansa, Dany and Cersei in how they’re using jewellery. 

The use of armor isn’t altogether new. She has been building her armor since Ned’s death. It prominently features in her two wedding dresses.

The rigidity of the shape is quite telling of her state and mindset. They essentially “encase” her as well and in that way appear like a shell around her. 

“For Sansa’s wedding dress the designer Michele Clapton wanted to have an embroidered band that wrapped around which symbolistically told Sansa’s life from the Tully and Stark beginnings to the entanglement with the Lannisters. Her story starts at her lower back where the Tully fish and Stark Direwolf entwine as we move round to the front the Lannister Lion is becoming dominant over the Direwolf and at the back neck the Lions head is stamped onto Sansa. The dress colour was still very much Sansa Stark and the embroidery had pale golden tones but woven through the story are ripe red pomegranates, the red colour symbolising the growing Lannister influence over her.” - Michele Carraghar

As I’ve also written before, these dresses parallel or make references to Lyanna. The additional appendage with embroidery around it is like Lyanna’s metallic brace at her wedding to Rhaegar. But there is more to it as Sansa’s season 3 wedding dress is not made by her but rather the Lannisters. 

“Obviously we imagined that the wedding dress has been commissioned by Cersei and the Lannisters for Sansa, and so the embroidery would have come from Cersei’s mind. We guessed that it wouldn’t be romantic or lovely and girly and pretty with dainty flowers, but a real strong message of dominance, saying that we own you now, Sansa.”

“Wedding days should be a joyous event for the bride, but, unfortunately, Sansa’s being forced into a marriage that she doesn’t want, into the Lannister family. For this dress, Michelle wanted it to be a confined, restricted bodice shape with bare, vulnerable arms. She wanted an embroidered band that would wrap around the bodice and tell Sansa’s life story.” - Michele Carragher to SCPR

So if it looks like an armor, it’s still her being forced into it and it is another form of abuse in its own way. It’s a cage. But it’s not that she won’t use some of it in the future by subverting it into her favour. 

According to Clapton Sansa does end up designing her second wedding dress paying respects to her family because it’s about her goal to take back her family home. 

“What struck me about Sansa’s wedding gown is that (much like Margaery’s second wedding gown) this one was wholly Sansa. Clapton says that was deliberate. “It’s Sansa trying to respect everyone that’s been before her. She finally feels like she can make Winterfell a family home again. So I wanted to incorporate pieces that represented her family.” There’s the animal fur of the wolf that also recalls the furs we saw Ned and Robb sport in earlier seasons. There’s the shape of the dress, which is very northern, and one her mother wore frequently. There’s the fish shaped closures, which represent her Tully heritage.” - Winteriscoming

“The shape was also engineered to look a bit like the statues in the crypt at Winterfell.” - Fashionista

The restrictive structure conveys how this wedding is yet another battlefield for Sansa, not a wedding she genuinely wants to enter. Oddly despite its rigid silhouette, the textures on it again are very gentle like the dress that is quilted with miniature patterns of wings playing into her bird/dragonfly iconography and the white fur on her back shaped like two wings from her back. There’s no beading here. While Sansa does pay respects to her family, this isn’t a wedding she wants to be at either and it is essentially driven by her desire to avenge her family that Littlefinger manipulates her into doing by convincing her she would be weak otherwise. As we know, what follows is that dress being ripped apart by the “wings” by Ramsay and she is abused further. 

So the phrase “as if she was actually sewn or laced into her dress—like there was no way in” is in response to that and her abuse and exploitation by the Lannisters and Littlefinger and her betrayals by others as well. It results in her sewing every layer into the other so they can almost merge into one another - even when it is made to appear hardened. She doesn’t just want a shell as a protective layer, she tries to sew herself into the shell so it’s impossible to remove. 

That kind of imagery sounds painful and quite tragic when you think of it. As powerful as this sounds in terms of her abusers, there’s a vulnerability in Sansa not wanting anyone to touch her or break through her walls. She’s afraid of believing in anyone and trusting them with her life completely again after being burned so many times. 

(to be continued…)

summary: who all do you ship with Sansa? and who all with Dany?
question: who all do you ship with Sansa? and who all with Dany?
answer:
In no particular order…

Sansa: Jon, Theon, Pod, Tyrion, Margaery, Dany, the Hound

Dany: Jon, Missendei, Sansa, Robb, Margaery

I’m not into Jorah x Dany or Tyrion x Dany because I enjoy them more as friendships, but I don’t hate them.
